those farmers don't have access

know the plight of small hold farmers my
grandfather as I said worked very hard
his entire life and no matter what the
crop was or how much came in it was
never enough to get us out of poverty it
was always the wrong crop it was always
the wrong time it was always too little
it was always too much and for that

a number of number of generations until
my father until and to myself so so my
point is this project does hit home in a
very unique way most people's

like this right
looks like my refrigerator unfortunately
I have three daughters and you know for

you know what's in the fridge dad what's

they tend to look at it but most of the

cents in a year but the next day it was

specifically let's talk about Mali in
Mali as I as I said just like in
in rural Arkansas there's no mechanism

there's no tractors there's no

there's no complicated chemicals to keep

and without much information about what
they're doing they are literally
surviving on a day to day basis and then
when they take the crops that do survive

if you only raised in this other crop we

who have the same crop that you have

half of what they were yesterday
or well you know if you just come back

let's talk a little bit about the

you know how do we begin to collect

how to avoid famine how to avoid pests
understanding whether how the weather is

market place for them to deliver their

would this project was all about so as I

Africa and specifically in Mali are
impoverished meaning they're very poor
they're isolated which means there's no
coops there's no associations there's
nothing that helps them to have a fair

struggling with the weather conditions
in the pests and the other diseases that

do not it is purely purely chance and

all of these children are impacted by
and by protection what I mean is what

or feed each other is most of you
probably know slavery is alive and well
today and one of the alternatives that
families have when they get into this

becomes an issue the impact to a
community and specifically the children
can be catastrophic
what's the benefits of the system well
if we can have farmers understand what
the weather's going to be like potential

cycle which I'll talk about a little bit
to develop grow and provide the right

decisions and can have a better outcome

said is very simple the idea is to
provide farmers with information that
impacts them through the entire
agricultural cycle so they can
understand what it is that they should
be planting if every farmer in the
community is planting maize or corn
maybe you should plant soybeans or beets
or something else so that the market
isn't flooded at a specific time the
other thing is to understand when to
harvest because everyone's harvesting if
everyone's harvesting at the same time
then you're flooding the market in the
buyer of those crops can pick and choose
the price that they'd like because they
know you don't have an alternative and
they know all the farmers are coming in
at the same time creates an incredible
disadvantage to the farmer and then
commercialization the ability for

have information and create coops and
other ways for them to work together to

they can understand what's acceptable to

so it's all about information to the
farmer through the entire agriculture
cycle so that they can make good and

information to pull that information

upcoming pests and and and insect

decision with the appropriate
